response: The image is a forecast map from the National Hurricane Center. It shows the projected path of Tropical Depression 17 in the Western Gulf of Mexico. The map indicates that the system has the potential to become a tropical storm by this afternoon, and its center should move across the northern Gulf coast tonight or Saturday morning. Flooding and strong winds are expected along the Central Gulf coast into the Lower Mississippi Valley through Saturday morning. Tornadoes are possible this evening across southeast Louisiana and Mississippi into southwest Alabama. There is no additional hazard associated with the possible future storm at Port of Pascagoula, MS.
ground_truth: Isolated tornadoes overnight Friday into Saturday; rough seas and hazardous navigation conditions in approaches and anchorages

The image shows a weather map and a chart of wind speed probabilities for various locations in the United States. The specific location of interest is Port of Pascagoula, MS. According to the image, the peak impact magnitude at Port of Pascagoula, MS, would be 15 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale (SSHWS). This scale is used by the National Hurricane Center (NHC) to categorize tropical cyclones by their potential damage. Category 4 and higher on the SSHWS are considered major hurricanes, while Category 1 and lower are considered tropical storms or depressions. The number 15 indicates a more severe storm, with sustained winds of at least 73 mph (118 km/h).
